recommended_movies: Dave Chappelle: For What it's Worth (2004)
To All the Boys I've Loved Before (2018)

simulated_ratings.title: Capitalism: A Love Story (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Moore’s broadside against corporate power aligns with my social-issue doc sweet spot, even if his style can be heavy-handed.

simulated_ratings.title: Dave Chappelle: For What it's Worth (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Smart and biting, but some raunch and dated bits dull my enthusiasm.

simulated_ratings.title: To All the Boys I've Loved Before (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sweet and charming with welcome representation, though it leans pretty formulaic.

simulated_ratings.title: Louis C.K.: Hilarious (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sharp observations undercut by a bro-y vulgarity that wears thin for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Pride (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Joyful, political, and big-hearted LGBTQ solidarity hits me right in the sweet spot.

simulated_ratings.title: Little Voice (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tender, performance-driven and quirky in a way I find endearing, if a bit uneven.

simulated_ratings.title: Antonia's Line (Antonia) (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Warm, feminist, multigenerational storytelling in a European register I love.

simulated_ratings.title: Dr. Horrible's Sing-Along Blog (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clever, small-scale musical wit with heart, even if the superhero trappings aren’t my thing.

simulated_ratings.title: 13th (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clear, urgent, and devastatingly argued

simulated_ratings.title: Frozen (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Catchy and pretty, but the Disney gloss keeps me at an arm’s length.

simulated_ratings.title: Girl in the Café, The (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quiet, human, and politically tinged romance that suits my taste for intimate drama.

simulated_ratings.title: Star Wars: The Last Jedi (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Ambitious ideas peeking through franchise noise still leave me feeling detached.

simulated_ratings.title: Louis C.K.: Chewed Up (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Talented, yes, but the crude shock humor and perspective don’t sit well with me.

simulated_ratings.title: The Fault in Our Stars (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Earnest and affecting in moments, yet too manipulative for my taste.

simulated_ratings.title: Feast (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Short, sweet, and emotionally sincere, with the dog’s-eye view totally working on me.

simulated_ratings.title: Great Day in Harlem, A (1994)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lovely archival reverie for music history buffs, if a touch niche for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Bo Burnham: what. (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Inventive, self-aware showmanship that tickles my brain as much as it entertains.

simulated_ratings.title: Bo Burnham: Inside (2021)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Formally daring, intimate, and resonant—exactly the kind of creative risk I adore.

simulated_ratings.title: Election (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Smart, razor-edged satire with characters I love to wrestle with.

simulated_ratings.title: Requiem for the American Dream (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Calm, incisive deconstruction of inequality that aligns with my interests.

simulated_ratings.title: Hasan Minhaj: Homecoming King (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Personal, funny, and socially observant in a way that lands for me.

simulated_ratings.title: (500) Days of Summer (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Playful structure and honesty about romance scratch my anti-formula itch.

simulated_ratings.title: Almost Famous (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Big-hearted, music-soaked coming-of-age that feels authentically lived-in.

simulated_ratings.title: Girls Town (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Raw, feminist teen drama whose solidarity and anger ring true.

simulated_ratings.title: Juno (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Witty and warm with a strong voice, even if the quirk sometimes shows.

simulated_ratings.title: Deep End, The (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tense, intimate family thriller with queer undercurrents I find compelling.

simulated_ratings.title: Inside Out (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Imaginative and emotionally intelligent in a way that really resonates with me.

simulated_ratings.title: Presto (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Polished and funny, though mostly a cute trifle for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Quills (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A provocative tussle with art, desire, and censorship that I admire more than love.

simulated_ratings.title: Garden State (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Some honest moments, but the indie affectations keep me at a distance.

recommended_movies: Cook the Thief His Wife & Her Lover, The (1989)
World According to Monsanto, The (monde selon Monsanto, Le) (2008)
Adventures of Milo and Otis, The (Koneko monogatari) (1986)

simulated_ratings.title: Cook the Thief His Wife & Her Lover, The (1989)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lush, provocative takedown of power and patriarchy that grips me even when the cruelty tests my limits.

simulated_ratings.title: Halloween (1978)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Iconic suspense I admire more than enjoy, as slasher mechanics leave me a bit cold.

simulated_ratings.title: Rush: Beyond the Lighted Stage (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Engaging craft and an affectionate portrait win me over even if the fandom isn’t quite mine.

simulated_ratings.title: Roma (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lyrical, intimate, and socially attuned in exactly the humane register that moves me deeply.

simulated_ratings.title: Phantasm IV: Oblivion (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Dreamy weirdness can’t overcome my impatience with lore-heavy horror sequels.

simulated_ratings.title: English Patient, The (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gorgeous and earnest, but the sweeping romance keeps me at a cool distance.

simulated_ratings.title: La La Land (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Charming and polished, yet its nostalgic gloss dulls the emotional bite for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Simple Plan, A (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A bleak, tight moral spiral that scratches my itch for character-driven tension.

simulated_ratings.title: The Power of the Dog (2021)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Slow-burn cruelty and queer undercurrents that I find gripping and thoughtfully crafted.

simulated_ratings.title: Oscar and Lucinda (a.k.a. Oscar & Lucinda) (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: An offbeat, literary romance with themes of faith and risk that mostly works for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Phantom Thread (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A prickly, precise power-play that fascinates me with its thorny romance.

simulated_ratings.title: Jeopardy (a.k.a. A Woman in Jeopardy) (1953)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lean, suspenseful stakes and a compelling female perspective keep me engaged.

simulated_ratings.title: Felix Lobrecht: Hype (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A few sharp bits, but the bro-ish edge and darkness don’t land for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Au Hasard Balthazar (1966)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Spare, devastating empathy that quietly wrecks me.

simulated_ratings.title: The Smile Man (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A tender, clever short with a high-concept heart that leaves a small, warm ache.

simulated_ratings.title: Cabaret (1972)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Seductive showmanship sharpened by politics—my kind of bittersweet spectacle.

simulated_ratings.title: World According to Monsanto, The (monde selon Monsanto, Le) (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A clear, enraging corporate exposé that hits my documentary sweet spot.

simulated_ratings.title: Crying Game, The (1992)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A complex, humane thriller whose queer and political layers resonate with me.

simulated_ratings.title: Pete's Dragon (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Warm, earnest family fantasy that works on me despite the Disney sheen.

simulated_ratings.title: Celebration, The (Festen) (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A raw, explosive confrontation of familial abuse with bracing moral clarity.

simulated_ratings.title: Spider (2002)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A hushed, unsettling character study I admire even if its chill keeps me slightly at a distance.

simulated_ratings.title: Adventures of Milo and Otis, The (Koneko monogatari) (1986)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A sweet animal odyssey that tugs at my soft spot for creature companionship.

simulated_ratings.title: Hotline (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: An intimate, empathetic look at connection that feels right in my documentary wheelhouse.

simulated_ratings.title: Adam Had Four Sons (1941)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Old-fashioned melodrama whose gender politics and contrivances keep me at arm’s length.

simulated_ratings.title: Camp Rock (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bubblegum formula and TV gloss I find hard to get through, despite decent intentions.

simulated_ratings.title: Funny Games (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: I respect the icy provocation, but the sadism makes the experience more punishing than rewarding for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Manchester by the Sea (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quiet, lived-in grief that feels authentic and deeply affecting to me.

simulated_ratings.title: Colossal (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A nerdy, conceptually playful doc-essay that intrigues me even when it meanders.

simulated_ratings.title: Tada's Do-It-All House (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gentle, low-key humanism with odd-couple warmth that suits my taste.

recommended_movies: Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery (1997)
Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me (1999)
Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan (1982)
Naked Gun: From the Files of Police Squad!, The (1988)

simulated_ratings.title: Saw (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The sadistic survival-game premise feels punishing and drowns out any human interest for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Some clever spy spoofing, but the groin-level gags and mugging wear me down.

simulated_ratings.title: Bubble Boy (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Broad, juvenile road-romance formula that grates more than it charms.

simulated_ratings.title: Half Baked (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Loose and affable, yet the stoner-raunch humor is too dopey for my taste.

simulated_ratings.title: Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bigger, louder, and cruder pushes me further away.

simulated_ratings.title: Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan (1982)
simulated_ratings.feeling: I respect the high-stakes sci-fi confrontation even if franchise spectacle isn’t my thing.

simulated_ratings.title: Very Brady Sequel, A (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cute kitsch and a few winks, but it’s a thin gag stretched long.

simulated_ratings.title: Bill & Ted's Bogus Journey (1991)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Goofy, imaginative detours win some points despite the doofus energy.

simulated_ratings.title: Loaded Weapon 1 (National Lampoon's Loaded Weapon 1) (1993)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Machine-gun spoof jokes with a juvenile streak that rarely land for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Plan 9 from Outer Space (1959)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Earnest, campy sci-fi curiosities amuse a little, but it’s mostly clunky.

simulated_ratings.title: Hollywood Knights, The (1980)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Prankish, bro-ish nostalgia that leaves me cold.

simulated_ratings.title: Glen or Glenda (1953)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Rough around the edges, but its early, empathetic trans-focused storytelling matters to me.

simulated_ratings.title: Beavis and Butt-Head Do America (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A few dumb laughs, mostly undercut by the adolescent vibe.

simulated_ratings.title: Dumb and Dumber To (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Exhaustingly juvenile retread with little warmth or wit to latch onto.

simulated_ratings.title: Hills Have Eyes, The (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The grim, punishing brutality feels numbing rather than meaningful.

simulated_ratings.title: Hot Shots! Part Deux (1993)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Rapid-fire spoofing gets occasional chuckles, but it’s too blunt and disposable.

simulated_ratings.title: Mortdecai (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Strained caper silliness and mannered mugging that never gels for me.

simulated_ratings.title: X (2022)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Slasher beats hold some intrigue, but the kill-count mechanics keep me at arm’s length.

simulated_ratings.title: Brady Bunch Movie, The (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Amusing fish-out-of-water shtick in doses, though the nostalgia gag runs thin.

simulated_ratings.title: Penguins of Madagascar (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Zippy and polished, yet too zany and disposable to linger.

simulated_ratings.title: Grave Encounters 2 (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Another horror sequel that ups the noise while draining my interest.

simulated_ratings.title: Prom Night (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Glossy teen-slasher formula that leaves me unmoved.

simulated_ratings.title: Ernest Scared Stupid (1991)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Good-natured but grating slapstick that isn’t my flavor of family fun.

simulated_ratings.title: Ernest Saves Christmas (1988)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Earnest sentiment can’t overcome the mugging and thin jokes.

simulated_ratings.title: Airplane II: The Sequel (1982)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Joke-a-minute spoofing occasionally hits but mostly feels mechanical.

simulated_ratings.title: Pain & Gain (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A bro-y, macho spin on the American dream that leaves me more weary than amused.

simulated_ratings.title: Metropolitan (1990)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Talky, wry, class-conscious chamber drama that lands squarely in my wheelhouse.

simulated_ratings.title: Freddy Got Fingered (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Aggressively crude, mean-spirited antics that repel rather than engage.

Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 (2011)
Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

simulated_ratings.title: Misérables, Les (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Humanist, politically tinged storytelling in a European register I really respond to.

simulated_ratings.title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The dour, franchise-heavy road movie feels stretched and keeps me at a cool distance.

simulated_ratings.title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The finale delivers emotion and craft, even if the spectacle-first stakes aren’t my favorite flavor.

simulated_ratings.title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Moody and character-focused in parts, but the franchise machinery blunts my engagement.

simulated_ratings.title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: I appreciate the resistance theme, though the blockbuster churn still leaves me a bit detached.

simulated_ratings.title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Set-piece thrills entertain in patches, but the tournament spectacle overwhelms the human beats I care about.

simulated_ratings.title: Sense and Sensibility (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Wry, humane class-and-romance drama in a mode that suits me.

simulated_ratings.title: Dreamlife of Angels, The (Vie rêvée des anges, La) (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A raw, intimate portrait of female friendship and precarity that sits squarely in my wheelhouse.

simulated_ratings.title: Ravenous (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Its satiric, cannibal-western mash-up intrigues me, but the grisly horror keeps me at arm’s length.

simulated_ratings.title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A darker, more character-conscious turn that engages me more than most entries.

simulated_ratings.title: 100 Days (1991)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The ESP melodrama and thriller beats feel dated and contrived for my taste.

simulated_ratings.title: Stupidstitious Cat (1947)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clever gags land here and there, though the slapstick vibe is mostly disposable for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Short Term 12 (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tender, clear-eyed, and humane in exactly the intimate register I love.

simulated_ratings.title: Perks of Being a Wallflower, The (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sincere, empathetic coming-of-age with music and friendship textures that work on me.

simulated_ratings.title: Mrs. Dalloway (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Literary introspection and social undercurrents in a quiet register I appreciate, if a touch cool.

simulated_ratings.title: Duchess, The (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Handsome, feminist-leaning period intrigue that I like even if the gloss softens the bite.

simulated_ratings.title: Paper Towns (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Earnest and occasionally charming, but the YA mystery-romance feels thin and schematic.

simulated_ratings.title: War Photographer (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: An austere, morally engaged documentary portrait that aligns with my nonfiction interests.

simulated_ratings.title: Son of the Sheik, The (1926)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A charming silent adventure with dated exoticism that tempers my enthusiasm.

simulated_ratings.title: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (2002)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Whimsical adventure has its charms, though the franchise formula keeps me at a remove.

simulated_ratings.title: Pride and Prejudice (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A pleasant behind-the-scenes glimpse that’s engaging if minor.

simulated_ratings.title: Warm Bodies (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cute and reasonably clever genre-blend that goes down easy without lingering much.

simulated_ratings.title: Bright Night (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Relationship tension and the supernatural wrinkle intrigue me, even if it may feel uneven.

simulated_ratings.title: Martyrs (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Its punishing extremity and sadism overwhelm any philosophical interest I might have.

simulated_ratings.title: Young Victoria, The (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Polished, tender period romance with enough political texture to keep me engaged.

simulated_ratings.title: Premachi Goshta (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A warm, sincere romance about trust that I find agreeable if conventional.

simulated_ratings.title: Toy Story Toons: Small Fry (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Breezy, witty Pixar mini that amuses without much emotional weight.

simulated_ratings.title: Boyhood (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lived-in, humane, time-spanning intimacy that moves me deeply.

simulated_ratings.title: Zeitgeist: The Movie (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Conspiratorial framing and overreach undercut the political critique I might otherwise engage with.
